awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Novel Circulation Control for Electric Aircraft
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be the accelerated adoption of electric flight. Currently, the limited range and payloads of small electric aircraft make them economically unviable on most routes.  Increased aerodynamic efficiency is required for longer range. The circulation control technology being developed generates extremely high lift only when needed (takeoff and landing), but unlike other propulsion-based approaches aimed at the same effect, it is low cost and allows for a smaller and more efficient wing without any mass or performance drawbacks for the cruise portion of flight where range is needed. More rapid adoption of electric aircraft will enhance US leadership in this nascent field, facilitate the use of the country’s 5000 small, regional airports for transformative, quiet, accessible, electric air mobility, and become a new area of economic growth in underserved parts of the country. Moreover, decarbonization is an urgent challenge in aviation, with the industry being among the least able to electrify. Radical new aerodynamic approaches and configurations must be adopted, such as those which the proposed technology will enable, to reach a true net zero future for air transportation.   

This project involves research and development of novel aerodynamic circulation control applied to the wings of electric planes to generate extremely high lift. The technology introduces a high-energy narrow jet of air over control surfaces like flaps, allowing for much higher deflections and potentially tripling the lift of a wing at takeoff and landing. Previously deemed too risky and expensive for commercial application by industry based on earlier concepts fueled by combustion engines and complex plumbing, this innovation simplifies the physical implementation in a way that is only now possible with the latest electric aircraft architectures. This project develops a combination of high-fidelity computational fluid dynamics simulations and physical aerodynamic testing to uncover the fundamental turbulent flow characteristics that must be produced to ensure that maximum wing lift coefficients of 4 to 5 can be achieved reliably, particularly in off-design conditions. Detailed performance modeling will establish benchmarks of existing vs. modified performance to include circulation control and then apply this data to an entirely new type of maximum efficiency wing that can become a new industry standard.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Decarbonization is the most urgent problem in aviation, but even the smallest electric or electrified aircraft remain barely viable due to the mass and energy density limitations of batteries compared to aviation fuel. NSF SBIR Phase I grant funding awarded to Seaflght Technologies supported the goal of developing and commercializing a novel form of active aerodynamic flow control for electrified aircraft that facilitates very high lift coefficients at takeoff and landing from a reduced wing area, allowing for substantial drag reductions in the cruise portion of a flight. The overall energy savings translate directly into increased range and payload.

Aircraft wings must be sized for takeoff, and generally incorporate flaps that feature increasing mass and complexity the larger the airframe or the shorter the desired takeoff run. The project team set out to develop a specific type of flow control – called circulation control – that involves blowing over portions of the wing to ensure that airflow remains smooth and follows the contours of the wing even at high flap angles. Normally flaps deflected beyond approximately 15 degrees will stall, creating high drag and limiting the amount of lift that can be generated. By energizing the airflow in this takeoff condition by actively injecting additional air near the surface, much higher flap deflections (therefore much higher lift) had in prior work been proven possible but with systems that added unsustainable additional mass and complexity. Seaflight’s approach was designed to be simple enough to avoid these penalties and impracticalities.

The team set out to answer the questions: what mass flow rates of air are required to maintain attached airflow over high flap deflections? What flap angles can be realistically achieved? What reductions in wing area can be achieved with the lift that can now be generated at takeoff and landing? And what energy saving would that translate to on a real-world platform?

Following extensive customer discovery among electric and electrified aircraft companies, a program of hundreds of computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations was undertaken based on a simple wing section fitted with the active control technology – at this stage, mass flow rates and blowing nozzle geometries were evaluated and optimized to establish the envelope of lift coefficients that could be achieved. The scientific R&D in this phase culminated in wind tunnel testing with a 4ft span wind tunnel model tested in the Lucas Low Speed Wind Tunnel at Caltech in Pasadena, California. The model was designed to replicate the simulated conditions, and allowed for flap deflections up to 60 degrees – far beyond a normal range of deflection for conventional aircraft. Variables included relative air velocity (effectively Reynolds number), blowing coefficients, flap deflections, and wing angles of incidence. From these results, the aerodynamic flow control was demonstrated to be remarkably effective by maintaining attached airflow, under certain circumstances, even at the highest flap deflections.    

The key high-level conclusions drawn were: 1) Seaflight’s particular embodiment of aerodynamic circulation control can be extremely effective at creating lift coefficients at least 3 times higher than a conventional wing/flap assembly; 2) the creation of this high amount of lift could allow for wing areas at least 30% smaller than would otherwise be needed for takeoff and landing. The combination of these two points facilitates electric aircraft that can have excellent short take-off and landing performance to access remote or constrained areas, and significantly improved cruise range and/or payload. Challenges relating to reliability and certifiability remain to be explored; it is a critical system that must be proven to be as robust and reliable as flaps themselves.

Aviation as a whole is responsible for 2.5 % of global C02 emissions and 3.5% of global anthropogenic climate change. Aviation greenhouse gas emissions from the US alone rank higher than the national total emissions of more than 150 countries. Electrifying all short haul flights by 2040 and all long-haul flights by 2045 can reduce US sector emissions be over 75%. Taken to formal commercialization following this initial de-risking stage, Seaflight Technologies’ aerodynamic circulation control technology can be a key enabler for accelerating the electrification of flight this decade and beyond by supporting faster and more widespread adoption without waiting for distant battery improvements.

 


Last Modified: 10/05/2024
Modified by: Graham C Doig

Image
  • Seaflight Technologies engineer Dr. Johan Melis installs a wing in the Caltech wind tunnel to test the company's novel active aerodynamic flow control. The technology generates a large amount of additional lift from a smaller wing area, allowing for more efficient aircraft.
    Graham Doig
    Creative Commons
    Graham C Doig
    Seaflight Technologies wind tunnel test
